Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u000.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Samantha Carter, pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, and respectfully moves this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody and parenting schedule for the minor child, Emily Carter.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as the minor child resides in the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Massachusetts places significant emphasis on maintaining frequent and continuing contact with both parents whenever possible, provided such contact is in the child’s best interests.

*See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.proposition: Massachusetts law is clear that the child's best interests are paramount in custody and parenting time determinations.
*See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets the Massachusetts removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and repeatedly characterizes the child’s best interests as the central and paramount consideration, even when also weighing parental interests. In articulating the removal standard, the court explains that all interests are considered, but frames the analysis around the child’s welfare and quality of life, confirming that best interests are the controlling criterion in custody-related determinations.
*See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts law is clear that the child's best interests are paramount in custody and parenting time determinations.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the longstanding Massachusetts rule that custody decisions turn on the ‘best interests of the child’ and describes that standard as the paramount concern in custody and visitation matters. The court applies that best-interests standard in reviewing the trial judge’s custody and parenting-time allocation, confirming that under Massachusetts law the child’s best interests control such determinations.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..raw_text: *See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..proposition: A material change in circumstances justifies modification of the original custody order.
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion directly cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 and explains that a Probate Court judge may modify an earlier custody judgment upon finding a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and that such modification must be in the children’s best interests. The court then applies this standard, upholding the judge’s finding that the mother’s successful rehabilitation from substance abuse constituted the required material change. This squarely supports the proposition that a material change in circumstances justifies modification of the original custody order, subject to the best‑interests analysis.
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’ … Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

*See Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608.raw_text: *See Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987)
*See Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608.proposition: The Court may consider the child’s preferences when determining a custody modification that serves the child’s best interests.
*See Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the role of the child’s stated preference in a custody determination. In evaluating custody of Tony, the court notes his expressed preference and states that such a preference, at his age, is a factor to be considered—though not decisive—within the broader best-interests analysis. This directly aligns with the proposition that a court may consider a child’s preferences in determining a custody modification in the child’s best interests.
*See Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608.relevant_excerpt: “Tony’s custody presents a closer question. His father appears to have indoctrinated him with some dislike for his mother, and he has expressed a preference for Bielefeld. … The preference of someone Tony’s age (ten at the time of the proceedings) is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered.”

*See Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (.proposition: Massachusetts places significant emphasis on maintaining frequent and continuing contact with both parents whenever possible, provided such contact is in the child’s best interests.
*See Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about the impact of domestic violence on children and the risks of awarding custody or shared custody to an abusive parent. It does not articulate a general Massachusetts policy emphasizing ‘frequent and continuing contact with both parents’ as an affirmative value; instead, it stresses that domestic violence must be given substantial weight in the best‑interests analysis and that shared custody requires special findings when a 209A order exists. Thus, the case is about constraining or scrutinizing shared custody in the presence of violence, not promoting frequent contact with both parents as a general rule.
*See Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (.relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ … We agree with the Appeals Court that such written findings should also be made attending specifically to the effects of domestic violence on the child and the appropriateness of the joint custody award in light of those effects.”

*See Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *See Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000)
*See Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Courts favor custody and parenting arrangements that promote the child’s emotional welfare.
*See Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The court repeatedly grounds its analysis in the statutory and common‑law ‘best interests of the child’ standard, expressly including the child’s overall welfare, not just physical needs. It emphasizes factors like emotional bonds, stimulation, enrichment, structure, and the importance of maintaining access to both parents, all of which relate directly to the child’s emotional well‑being. Thus the opinion supports the general proposition that courts favor custody and parenting arrangements that promote the child’s emotional welfare.
*See Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .… a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests…. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child[ ] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future…. The judge emphasized that ‘[a]ccess for the child to each parent is an important consideration for the [c]ourt.’”

*See Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20.proposition: The continuing jurisdiction of the Probate and Family Court to modify custody orders exists to serve this purpose (*See Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (1981)), and this principle applies squarely to the instant matter.
*See Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20.support_reasoning: The opinion in Heistand deals with contempt, modification of child support, termination of alimony, amendments to pleadings, attorneys’ fees, and tax allocation, but it does not discuss the Probate and Family Court’s ‘continuing jurisdiction’ to modify custody orders or the purpose of that jurisdiction. Modification is mentioned only in the context of changing support based on a material change in circumstances, not as a statement about the court’s ongoing jurisdiction or its rationale. Using this case as authority for the quoted proposition about continuing custody jurisdiction misstates its holding and subject matter.
*See Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20.relevant_excerpt: “In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.”
